hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of a binary tree. Each node has a value, and it can have a left child and a right child. You'll need to traverse the tree to access nodes and their relationships.
Remember that a grandparent is the parent of a node's parent. To find nodes with even-valued grandparents, you'll need to keep track of both the current node and its parent as you traverse.
Consider using a depth-first search (DFS) approach to traverse the tree. This will allow you to explore each node and its children systematically.
As you traverse, maintain a way to check if the grandparent node is even-valued. This means you should pass the values of the current node and its parent to the recursive function.
Think about how to sum the values of nodes that meet the criteria. You can initialize a sum variable at the beginning of your function and update it whenever you find a valid node.
Don't forget to handle the base cases. If the current node is null, you should return. Also, consider what happens when you reach leaf nodes.
Make sure to check the constraints of the problem. The number of nodes is between 1 and 10,000, and node values range from 1 to 100. This suggests that your solution should be efficient.
While traversing, you can use a helper function that takes three parameters: the current node, its parent, and its grandparent. This way, you can easily access the values you need.
When you check if a grandparent is even, remember to only sum the values of the current node if the grandparent is indeed even. You can do this with a simple conditional check.
Finally, ensure your function returns the accumulated sum after the entire tree has been traversed. This will be your final answer for nodes with even-valued grandparents.

questionNotes: Constraints: The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [1, 10^4].
Return 0 if there are no nodes with an even-valued grandparent.
A grandparent of a node is defined as the parent of its parent.
